Capillary blood pressure: hydrostatic pressure exerted on the capillary wall by the blood. Forces fluid out of capillary 2. Plasma colloid osmotic pressure (also known as oncotic pressure): force caused by plasma proteins which remain in plasma, which exerts an osmotic effect on water. Forces fluid into the plasma compartment 3. Interstitial fluid pressure: hydrostatic pressure exerted by the interstitial fluid on the outside of the capillary wall. Forces fluid into capillaries. 4. Interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure: the protein concentration in the interstitium is normally very low, and so this force is close to zero. Filtration is greatest at the arterial end of the capillary â€¢ Hydrostatic forces favouring filtration are greatest at the arterial ends of capillaries â€¢ Oncotic osmotic pressure predominates at the venous ends of the capillaries ensuring 90% of the fluid is reabsorbed â†’ this creates a filtration- absorption imbalance â€¢ This excess fluid is collected by the lymphatic system Rhoades & Pflanzer, 2003 Cardiovascular System â€¢ The heart - the driving force propels blood around the body â€¢ Arterial system the distribution channels â€¢ The microcirculation the exchange vessels â€¢ The venous system the blood reservoirs, return blood to the heart Single and dual circulatory systems Single circuits: Advantage: Blood passing through the gills is fully oxygenated when it moves into the tissues. Limitation: In passing through the gills, blood loses much of its pressure developed by contraction of the heart. This limits rate of oxygen delivery to the rest of the body. Dual circuits: Effectively two heart pumps and two circulations Flow must be matched in the two circulations More efficient, higher rate of oxygen supply to tissues Dual circulation â€¢ The LEFT side of the heart pumps OXYGENATED blood to the SYSTEMIC circulation â€¢ The RIGHT side of the heart pumps DEOXYGENATED blood to the PULMONARY circulation â€¢ Two separate vascular loops â€“ both originate and terminate at the heart Blood flows in one direction! the driving force propels blood around the body â€¢ Arterial system the distribution channels â€¢ The microcirculation the exchange vessels â€¢ The venous system the blood reservoirs, return blood to the heart The pumping system: role of the heart â€¢ The heart consists of two muscular pumps â€¢ Blood flow through organs is passive â€¢ Right heart pump provides energy to push blood through pulmonary vessels â€¢ Left heart pump provides energy to push blood through the systemic organs The pumping system: role of the heart â€¢ Each side consists of two chambers: an atrium and a ventricle â€¢ Heart valves allow flow of blood in one direction only â€¢ Systole is the phase of the cardiac cycle when the muscle cells are contracting â€¢ Diastole is the phase where muscle cells relax â€¢ The left and right pumps are arranged in series Pathway of blood flow through the heartCoordinated pumping of the heart â€¢ Efficient pumping requires coordinated contraction of cardiac muscle cells â€¢ Contraction is triggered when an action potential sweeps over the cell membrane â€¢ Coordination is achieved primarily by conduction of action potentials between cells via gap junctions that connect cells https://www.78stepshealth.us/human-physiology/cardiac-and-smooth-muscles.html Coordinated pumping of the heart â€¢ The heart has a specialised conduction system â€¢ Sinoatrial node (SA) node is the pacemaker â€“ it initiates the action potential â€¢ Conduction system ensures that all of the cells work together to produce efficient pumping of the heart Coordinated pumping of the heart Effective cardiac pumping requires: â€¢ Regular, synchronised contractions â€¢ Valves that open and close normally (no leakes) â€¢ Adequate force of muscle contraction â€¢ Adequate filling of ventricles â€¦â€¦ or there will be adverse consequences â€“ stay tuned for the next chapter of this story!
